thread.title: Ashes 2015: Mitchell Johnson Steve Smith show England exactly what they’re capable of after slow starts to the series |
thread.title_full: Ashes 2015: Mitchell Johnson and Steve Smith show England exactly what they’re capable of after slow starts to the series | The Courier-Mail

author: couriermail.com.au
title: Ashes 2015: Mitchell Johnson Steve Smith show England exactly what they’re capable of after slow starts to the series |
text:
Steve Smith smashed a maiden Test double hundred, just the third by an Australian at the home of cricket, to power the resurgent tourists to a commanding 8-566 (dec) before the three amigos in the pace attack came out firing.
For England’s bowlers the Lord’s wicket played like a road, but Johnson, Josh Hazlewood and Starc made it fly like it was the Gabba and the home side were left still 481 runs in arrears at 4-85, needing another 282 runs just to avoid the follow-on.
If it weren’t for a backs-to-the-wall partnership from captain Alastair Cook (21 not out) and Ben Stokes (38no), England might have already been planning for Birmingham ... TAP HERE TO READ BEN HORNE’S MATCH REPORT IN FULL
MATCH CENTRE: TAP HERE FOR FULL SECOND TEST SCORECARD AND STATS

COLMAN: CAPTAIN’S FAILINGS MASKED BY SHEER CHANCE

SCARE: ROGERS HELPED BY POST-HUGHES HELMET
CONFIDENTIAL: WARNER’S CHEEKY DIG AT BRITISH PRESS
Good day for ...
MITCHELL JOHNSON
He says he never doubted himself during a middlein start to the series, and he certainly didn’t leave anyone wondering on Day 2 with a ferocious display that rewound to the days when his gallops towards the wicket was one of the most exhilarating sights in world sport.
STEVE SMITH
Another who copped plenty of snark after the first Test for having the gumption to accumulate statistics that put him in the same rarefied air as the world’s best batsmen. A double Ashes century at Lord’s puts him unequivocally in Bradman territory.
Steve Smith has reached his double century on Day Two at Lord’s 0:54 Play video
Cricket: Steve Smith has reached the remarkable milestone of a double century. Smith continued his incredible innings on Day Two despite losing teammate Chris Rogers with whom he formed a 284 run partnership the highest by two Aussies at Lord's.
Fox Sports 19 Jul 2015 Sport/Cricket/Ashes/Highlights
Bad day for ...
JOE ROOT
Had perfected that cheeky grin of his with a series of early let-offs but his luck finally ran out as Australia set out to unsettle him from the off. His wicket, claimed with a screamer by the on-fire Johnson, turned a shaky start for England into a full-blown 4-30 crisis.
THE ECB
A cunning (alleged) plan to deaden pitches in a bid to blunt Johnson and Co is biting England right where it hurts. Turns out you can’t control tosses. And no surface can stop Johnson when he’s in this kind of form.
Play of the day ...
Steve Smith has reached his double century on Day Two at Lord’s 0:54 Play video

Fox Sports 19 Jul 2015 Sport/Cricket/Ashes/Highlights
What the Poms are saying ...
MARTIN SAMUEL — Daily Mail
“We appear to have opened a portal to the past in NW8. Suddenly, it’s 2013 all over again. Mitchell Johnson is ferocious, England are in disarray and if this Test lasts five days it will only be because Sunday’s forecast has turned watery. Much like England’s batsmen.
“Scoreboard pressure. Yes, yes, we know. It was always going to be a different proposition to bat once Australia had amassed a cricket score that was like, well, a cricket score. Yet even with 566 to chase down – or 367 to avoid the follow on, which would be the first step to earning a draw – there really wasn’t much excuse for this.”
England's new ball struggles at Lord's 0:40 Play video
Cricket: Following Australia's impressive haul in the first innings at Lords, England fall further behind the pace as they struggle with the new ball
Fox Sports 18 Jul 2015 Sport/Cricket/Ashes/Highlights
MIKE ATHERTON — The Times
“When Michael Clarke’s team came at England after tea, after the eventual declaration, there was a ferocity and intensity to their out-cricket that recalled the nightmarish months in Australia during 2013-14, when, inspired by Mitchell Johnson, England capitulated meekly and without rejoinder.
“With more than 550 on the board and a short session to bowl, the final two hours of the day presented a perfect storm, which England’s top order was unable to weather.
“This time it was not just Johnson but his fellow left-armer, Mitchell Starc, who began things off at the Pavilion End, and Josh Hazlewood, who probed with the new ball from the Nursery End with the kind of surgical precision of which Glenn McGrath would have been proud. With as many as five slips in place, and catchers dotted around in front of batsmen, Australia suddenly looked a very different team, Clarke a very different captain.
“This was classic Ashes cricket that thankfully pushed the tameness of the previous day’s encounter from the memory.”
Tweet of the day ...
News has reached New York of a nightmare in St John’s Wood. Please let it be no more than wicked rumour … #ashes
— Stephen Fry (@stephenfry) July 17, 2015
Image of the day
Mitchell Johnson gets airborne after taking the wicket of England’s Joe Root. Source: AFP
What the players are saying:
MITCHELL JOHNSON
“I didn’t actually (doubt myself) at all. I’ve felt the same since (blitzing England in 2013-14) really. Nothing has changed for me.
“It would be nice to have those (England) scars come back out. It was a plan to go hard at Root and not let him settle.
“There has been times when I’ve been a bit flat maybe and haven’t bowled 150 clicks, but I’m still trying to hit the wicket hard and bowl a good rhythm.
“The ball has been swinging over here which has been amazing and when the ball is swinging at good pace it makes it more difficult (for the batsmen).”
STUART BROAD
“It’s always a tricky period when you’ve conceded a lot of runs to then go out and bat for 30 overs.
“It’s always a big test for you and I think mentally we didn’t switch on for 20 minutes — and lost four wickets.
“We’re hoping for blue sky in the morning and our aim is to get up to that follow-on because if we do Australia will have to bat again, and that takes a lot of time out of the game.
“Cooky and Stokesy applied themselves, played their game-plans really well.
“There’s no demons in this wicket. We’ve got 16 wickets left in the Test match, so I certainly expect a couple of big hundreds in there at some stage.”
